caption: Government supporters at a political rally for Mr. Maduro in Caracas.

result.explanation: The image shows a crowd of people holding flags and signs that appear to be in support of Maduro.  The location appears to be Caracas, given the context and visual clues.  Maduro's image is visible on a sign held up within the crowd. Therefore, the caption and entities align well with the visual content.

candidates.title: Venezuela protests: Large anti-Maduro march held in Caracas
candidates.content:
Hundreds of thousands of people have marched through the Venezuelan capital, Caracas, to protest against President Nicolas Maduro.
Opposition supporters, staging their largest rally for two years, called for Mr Maduro's removal.
They blame him for Venezuela's economic crisis and accuse the electoral commission of delaying a referendum that could shorten his stay in power.
Mr Maduro's supporters also rallied in large numbers.
He accuses the opposition of trying to stage a coup.
The opposition said close to a million people turned out for their march, dubbed the "Takeover of Caracas", but the government disputed the figures.
"We have shown to the world the importance of Venezuela and how much it wants change," said opposition politician Jesus Torrealba.
Dressed predominantly in white, they chanted "we are going to bring down Maduro".
Protesters said they had enough of the policies of the governing United Socialist Party of Venezuela.
"We are going to defeat hunger, crime, inflation and corruption. They've done nothing in 17 years. Their time is finished," Naty Gutierrez told Reuters news agency.
A small group of protesters clashed with riot police as the peaceful rally ended.
"The nation has triumphed. They wanted to intimidate the people but the people are here," said Mr Maduro at a rally in central Caracas he said was attended by 30,000 people.
"We have defeated an attempted coup that tried to fill Venezuela and Caracas with violence, death," he said.
The opposition hopes the march will pressure the electoral authorities into allowing them to launch the second petition needed to trigger the recall referendum as soon as possible.
Timing is key as the date when the referendum is held will determine what happens next.
If a referendum should go against the president before 10 January, new elections will be held, which the opposition hopes to win.
But if it is held after that date and Mr Maduro is recalled, his loyal vice-president will serve out the end of his term until 2019.
candidates.description: Hundreds of thousands of people marched through the Venezuelan capital to protest against President Nicolas Maduro, while a rival march is also held.

result.explanation: Source 1 explicitly mentions that "Mr Maduro's supporters also rallied in large numbers."  This directly supports the news caption's assertion of a political rally for Mr. Maduro with government supporters. The source further details that Maduro himself spoke at a rally in Caracas, attended by 30,000 people.
result.supporting_points: Source 1: "Mr Maduro's supporters also rallied in large numbers."

final_result.explanation: The caption "Government supporters at a political rally for Mr. Maduro in Caracas" aligns well with the image and corroborating evidence.  Internal validation reveals a high confidence score of 8, primarily due to the strong visual cues within the image. The image depicts a large crowd holding flags and signs clearly supporting Maduro, with his image visible on a sign within the crowd. The setting appears consistent with Caracas based on visual clues and the context of the event. External validation further strengthens this conclusion, achieving a confidence score of 8. A reliable source directly mentions "Mr. Maduro's supporters also rallied in large numbers," which directly supports the caption's assertion. The source also mentions Maduro speaking at a rally in Caracas, attended by a large number of people, adding to the consistency between the caption and external information.  There is no significant discrepancy between the internal and external checks. Both checks independently arrive at a high confidence level, indicating a strong alignment between the caption, the image content, and external evidence. The slight difference in confidence score (8 vs. 8) is negligible and does not impact the overall assessment. There is no uncertainty based on available evidence; the caption accurately describes the scene.
final_result.validation_summary: Both internal and external validation strongly support the accuracy of the caption, with high confidence scores.  The image content clearly depicts a pro-Maduro rally in Caracas, consistent with external source information. No discrepancies were found.
